title: What’s that ringing in your ears? - Marc Fagelson

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the condition where a person hears a constant ringing or buzzing sound without any external source of noise?

options.label: B
options.text: To distinguish between silence and sound

options.text: To mask tinnitus and reduce stress

options.label: C
options.text: It can be cured with sound therapy

options.label: D
options.text: It can be cured with medication

options.label: B
options.text: Different branches used disparate methodologies and lacked a shared language.

options.label: C
options.text: Mathematicians relied heavily on logic and formal proofs.

options.text: The field was led by a few influential mathematicians.

options.label: B
options.text: To establish a consistent logical framework unifying every branch of mathematics.

options.label: C
options.text: To introduce new mathematical objects and definitions.

options.label: D
options.text: To emphasize the importance of intuition in mathematics.

options.label: B
options.text: As bridges between two groups that establish logical relationships.

options.label: C
options.text: As mathematical objects with unique properties.

options.label: D
options.text: As abstract principles with no practical applications.

options.label: A
options.text: Math was a rigorous science that relied heavily on logic.

options.label: B
options.text: Math was an intuitive science, and an over-dependence on logic constrained creativity.

options.label: C
options.text: Math was a fragmented field with no shared language.

options.label: D
options.text: Math was a field led by a few influential mathematicians.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the group of scholars publish their work under a collective pseudonym, Nicolas Bourbaki?

options.label: A
options.text: To mark the occasion of revolutionizing the field of mathematics.

options.label: B
options.text: To establish a consistent logical framework unifying every branch of mathematics.

options.label: C
options.text: To introduce new mathematical objects and definitions.

options.label: D
options.text: To emphasize the importance of intuition in mathematics.

multiple-choice.question: How did the group maintain the illusion of Nicolas Bourbaki's existence?

options.label: A
options.text: They sent telegrams in his name and announced his daughter's wedding.

options.label: B
options.text: They published his work under his real name.

options.label: C
options.text: They kept his identity a secret from the public.

options.label: D
options.text: They never publicly acknowledged his existence.

multiple-choice.question: How did the group end the joke of Nicolas Bourbaki's existence in 1968?

options.label: A
options.text: They revealed his true identity to the public.

options.label: B
options.text: They printed his obituary, complete with mathematical puns.

options.label: C
options.text: They stopped publishing work under his name.

options.label: D
options.text: They denied his existence from the beginning.

multiple-choice.question: What is Nicolas Bourbaki's lasting legacy in the field of mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: He is associated with a single major discovery that changed the field.

options.label: B
options.text: His influence informs much current research, and the modern emphasis on formal proofs owes a great deal to his rigorous methods.

options.label: C
options.text: He introduced new mathematical objects and definitions that are still used today.

options.label: D
options.text: He led a group of scholars in revolutionizing the field of mathematics.

title: What can DNA tests really tell us about our ancestry? - Prosanta Chakrabarty

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the human genome is shared among all humans?
What percentage of the genome contains information distinct about an individual's ancestry?
What is the process called when chromosomes within each pair swap some sections during the formation of sex cells?
Why can two sisters have different DNA test results for their ancestry, despite sharing the same parents?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have different numbers of chromosomes

options.label: B
options.text: Because recombination occurs uniquely in each sex cell

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have different numbers of genes

options.label: D
options.text: Because they have different genetic markers

multiple-choice.question: What do commercial DNA tests use to determine an individual's ancestry?

options.label: B
options.text: Less than 1% of the 1% of the genome that varies among individuals

options.label: C
options.text: The 99% of the genome shared among all humans

multiple-choice.question: What is the assumption behind DNA tests that compare an individual's genetic markers to those of people living in a particular region?

options.label: A
options.text: That the individual has ancestors from that region

options.label: B
options.text: That the individual has visited that region

options.label: C
options.text: That the individual has genetic markers unique to that region

options.label: D
options.text: That the individual shares genetic markers with people currently living in that region, indicating ancestors from the same place

multiple-choice.question: Why may DNA test results change over time?

options.label: B
options.text: Because more people get their genomes sequenced and are added to the database

options.label: C
options.text: Because the test becomes more accurate

multiple-choice.question: What does a result of 2% Neanderthal on a DNA test indicate?

options.label: A
options.text: That the individual is 2% less human

options.label: B
options.text: That the individual has 2% of the Neanderthal genome

options.label: C
options.text: That the individual has Neanderthal ancestors from interbreeding that occurred around 40,000 years ago

options.label: D
options.text: That the individual has 2% of the genome shared among all humans

multiple-choice.question: Why are many indigenous peoples not well-represented in DNA test results?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have not had their genomes sequenced

options.label: B
options.text: Because they have a different type of DNA

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are not part of the 99% of the genome shared among all humans

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not part of the 1% of the genome that varies among individuals

multiple-choice.question: What is a limitation of using DNA tests to determine an individual's ancestry?

options.label: A
options.text: They can only provide information about an individual's parents

options.label: B
options.text: They can only provide information about an individual's grandparents

options.label: C
options.text: They may not be able to detect ancestors from certain regions or populations

options.label: D
options.text: They can provide information about an individual's entire ancestry with 100% certainty

title: When is a pandemic over?

multiple-choice.question: What does the World Health Organization (WHO) declare when a highly infectious disease is spreading worldwide?
What is the main factor that determines when the WHO will declare a pandemic over?

options.label: B
options.text: The rate of transmission dropping significantly

multiple-choice.question: What are the three main options that global governments have to respond to a pandemic?

options.label: A
options.text: Contain and Eradicate, Delay and Vaccinate, and Coordinate and Crush

options.label: B
options.text: Race through it, Delay and Vaccinate, and Coordinate and Crush

options.label: C
options.text: Lockdown and Quarantine, Social Distancing, and Vaccination

options.label: D
options.text: Testing and Tracing, Treatment and Prevention, and Vaccination

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential outcome of the "Race through it" strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: The pandemic ends quickly with minimal loss of life

options.label: B
options.text: The virus spreads slowly, allowing for vaccine development

options.label: C
options.text: Millions to hundreds of millions of people die

options.label: D
options.text: The pandemic is contained within a few months

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of slowing the spread of the virus in the "Delay and Vaccinate" strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: To allow for the development of a vaccine

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce the number of deaths

options.label: C
options.text: To contain the pandemic within a few months

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the population needs to receive a vaccine to achieve herd immunity?
What is the critical factor in the "Coordinate and Crush" strategy?

options.label: C
options.text: Containing the pandemic within a few months

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential risk of the "Coordinate and Crush" strategy?

options.label: B
options.text: The virus is not completely eradicated

options.label: D
options.text: The pandemic spreads to more countries

multiple-choice.question: Which strategy is generally considered the best option?
What is the potential long-term benefit of the pandemic?

options.label: A
options.text: The development of new treatments and prevention methods

options.label: D
options.text: The increase in the number of deaths
